facts: Earth’s outer crust is broken into moving tectonic plates that can cause earthquakes and build mountains.
The highest layer of Earth’s atmosphere is so thin that satellites can travel through it with little air resistance.
Most volcanoes on Earth are found along plate boundaries, especially around the Pacific Ocean in the “Ring of Fire.”
Sedimentary rock often forms in layers, and those layers can preserve fossils of ancient plants and animals.
Water expands when it freezes, which is why ice floats and can crack rocks through repeated freezing and thawing.
Earth’s magnetic field helps protect us by deflecting many charged particles from the Sun, creating auroras near the poles.
The water on Earth is constantly recycled through the water cycle, including evaporation, condensation, precipitation, and runoff.
